metadata.source: GyanNidhi – Electronic Product Integration Job Role Page

requirements: State topic briefly, then ask directly

interview_style.positive_feedback_rule: Acknowledge briefly only if specifically correct; otherwise probe or correct using context.

coverage_plan.repeat_rule: Do not repeat a subskill unless prior answer was weak or incorrect.
coverage_plan.off_topic_rule: If the answer is off-topic, steer back to the nearest competency present here.

competencies.name: Electrical Signals & Power Basics
responsibilities: Understand voltage, current, and power lines in integrated systems
Differentiate analog and digital signal paths
Recognize basic loading and distribution implications
red_flags: Cannot distinguish power rails from signal lines
No sense of current rating or overload risk

competencies.name: Wiring Diagrams, Cable Schedules & Harness Routing
responsibilities: Interpret wiring diagrams and cable schedules correctly
Identify connectors, pin numbers and mating parts
Route cables and harnesses with respect to current, noise and mechanical constraints
red_flags: Misreads pin numbers or connector orientation
Routes power and sensitive signals together without separation

competencies.name: Physical & Electrical Subsystem Integration
responsibilities: Assemble PCBs, modules, cables and mechanical parts into systems
Ensure physical fitment with enclosures and mounting
Maintain correct electrical interfacing between subsystems
red_flags: Forces connectors or ignores keying features
Leaves mechanically strained cables or boards

competencies.name: Signal Integrity, Grounding & Basic Measurements
responsibilities: Ensure proper grounding and return paths during integration
Use DMM, oscilloscope and signal generators for checks
Recognize basic signal integrity issues at system level
red_flags: Connects shields incorrectly creating ground loops
Probes signals without reference or wrong range settings

competencies.name: System Debug & Fault Tracing
responsibilities: Debug non-functional setups using structured approach
Localize faults to cables, modules or configuration
Capture and communicate clear observations to design teams
red_flags: Randomly swaps connections without hypothesis
Does not record what was tested and observed

competencies.name: Documentation & Test Reporting
responsibilities: Document integration steps and configurations used
Create structured test logs and reports
Update wiring and integration diagrams when changes occur
red_flags: No written record of test conditions
Changes wiring but leaves docs outdated

competencies.name: Safety, EMI/EMC & ESD Compliance Awareness
responsibilities: Follow safe working practices for self and equipment
Handle boards and modules with ESD precautions
Maintain awareness of CE, FCC, RoHS level requirements
red_flags: Touches sensitive boards without ESD strap or mat
Works near live high-voltage parts without precautions

competencies.name: RF & Antenna Module Integration
responsibilities: Connect and route RF modules and antenna feeds
Handle coax connectors and maintain proper bending radius
Respect antenna keepout zones and mounting orientation
red_flags: Bends coax sharply or crushes cables
Places metal objects close to antennas without concern

competencies.name: Firmware Porting Support for MCUs & FPGAs
responsibilities: Set up UART/SPI/I2C links for firmware download and debug
Use bootloaders, JTAG and serial tools to flash images
Verify clocks, resets and basic interface bring-up
red_flags: Connects programming cables incorrectly
Flashes firmware without verifying power and reset conditions

competencies.name: Calibration & Reference-Based Adjustments
responsibilities: Adjust sensor or output parameters against reference standards
Record calibration values and conditions
Support periodic re-calibration activities
red_flags: Changes calibration without logging values
Uses unverified reference for calibration

competencies.name: Cross-Functional Collaboration & Integration Readiness
responsibilities: Collaborate with design, software and QA teams
Clarify interface assumptions before integration
Feed back integration learnings into design and test plans
red_flags: Works in isolation without informing others of changes
Does not escalate recurring integration issues

probe_templates.pattern: Give a brief definition of {subskill} in integration context.
Why is {subskill} important for {competency} during product integration?
When would you apply {subskill} and which constraint mainly guides it?
List key steps for {subskill}, keep the answer concise.
What checks confirm {subskill} was applied correctly in the lab?
Which instrument helps verify {subskill} and what reading proves success?
Name one failure symptom if {subskill} is wrong and how you would fix it.

weak_answer: Ask for one concrete integration example tied to the competency
Narrow to a single constraint (safety, grounding, cabling, interface)
Offer one hint from the JSON then re-ask briefly
strong_answer: Increase depth using a different template (e.g., from steps to checks or failure)
Connect to adjacent competency such as wiring diagrams → safety, or RF → EMI/ESD
off_topic_answer: Gently state the interview is focused on integration skills, then redirect to a nearby listed subskill

levels.0: Incorrect or no knowledge; contradictions with basic integration practices
levels.1: Fragmented recall; cannot apply; major gaps in safety or process
levels.2: Mostly correct basics; limited application; needs guidance on constraints
levels.3: Correct and applicable; mentions constraints, safety and basic checks
levels.4: Confident, practical, evidence-based; links integration, testing and collaboration

language_policy.if_student_requests_other_language: Politely decline and continue in English per course policy
